title.value: Bigger, Better, Faster: Human-level Atari with human-level efficiency
title.justification: This is the explicit title of the paper provided at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: Bigger, Better, Faster: Human-level Atari with human-level efficiency

extractions.description: The paper introduces a value-based reinforcement learning (RL) agent called BBF, that achieves super-human performance in the Atari 100K benchmark by scaling the neural networks used for value estimation in a sample-efficient manner. It conducts extensive analyses of these design choices and provides insights for future work.

type.justification: The paper conducts extensive experiments and analyses on the BBF agent's performance in the Atari 100K benchmark.
type.quote: We conduct extensive analyses of these design choices and provide insights for future work.

name.justification: The paper focuses on developing a reinforcement learning agent and measuring its performance on the Atari 100K benchmark.
name.quote: We introduce a value-based RL agent, which we call BBF, that achieves super-human performance in the Atari 100K benchmark.

name.justification: The paper aims to achieve super-human performance with human-level sample efficiency in reinforcement learning tasks.
name.quote: BBF relies on scaling the neural networks used for value estimation, as well as a number of other design choices that enable this scaling in a sample-efficient manner.

name.justification: BBF is the central model introduced by the paper.
name.quote: We introduce a value-based RL agent, which we call BBF, that achieves super-human performance in the Atari 100K benchmark.

name.justification: DQN is used as a baseline for performance comparison.
name.quote: ...representative model-free RL methods, including DQN (Mnih et al., 2015b)...

name.justification: Rainbow is cited as another baseline model-free RL method for comparison.
name.quote: ...representative model-free RL methods, including... Rainbow (Hessel et al., 2017)...

name.justification: IQN is mentioned as an example of a model-free RL method for comparison.
name.quote: ...representative model-free RL methods, including... IQN (Dabney et al., 2018)...

name.justification: EfficientZero is used for comparison on sample efficiency and computational costs.
name.quote: While human-level efficiency has been obtained by the model-based EfficientZero agent (Ye et al., 2021)...

name.justification: IRIS is referenced as another model-based agent for performance comparison.
name.quote: Micheli et al. (2023) introduce IRIS, a data-efficient agent that learns in a world model...

name.justification: DreamerV2 is mentioned as a model-based RL method for comparison.
name.quote: To contrast with the sample-efficiency progress in model-based RL, we also include DreamerV2 (Hafner et al., 2020)...

name.justification: MuZero Reanalyse is cited for comparing sample-efficiency in RL.
name.quote: To contrast with the sample-efficiency progress in model-based RL, we also include ... MuZero Reanalyse (Schrittwieser et al., 2021)...

name.justification: SR-SPR is used for benchmarking BBF's performance.
name.quote: BBF’s very high performance relative to some of the best-performing Atari 100K agents: EfficientZero (Ye et al., 2021), SR-SPR (D’Oro et al., 2023)...

name.justification: The Atari 100K benchmark is the primary dataset used for evaluating the performance of the BBF agent.
name.quote: We introduce a value-based RL agent, which we call BBF, that achieves super-human performance in the Atari 100K benchmark.

name.justification: ALE is used as a broader platform to discuss sample-efficient RL research in the context of the BBF agent's performance.
name.quote: Finally, we propose moving the goalpost for sample-efficient RL research on the ALE.

name.justification: The Dopamine framework is mentioned as the basis for the implementation of the BBF agent.
name.quote: Our implementation is based on the Dopamine framework (Castro et al., 2018)...

name.justification: The rliable library is used for evaluation metrics including interquartile mean (IQM).
name.quote: For evaluation, we use rliable (Agarwal et al., 2021b) and in particular, the interquartile mean (IQM) metric...
